intro: Hyacinthella leucophaea subsp. atchleyi, commonly known as the Atchley's hyacinthella, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its showy, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pale pink. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. It has linear, grass-like leaves and produces clusters of fragrant blooms in spring. Due to its limited distribution, it is considered a rare and endangered species in its native range.
